alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for incidental overnight expenses
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers covering the cost of personal expenses on overnight business trips
title: Expenses and benefits: incidental overnight expenses

table.body:
As an employer providing incidental overnight expenses to your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

##What’s included

'Incidental overnight expenses' are personal (non-business) expenses incurred by an employee while travelling overnight on business.

Examples of incidental expenses are:

* buying newspapers
* paying for laundry
* phoning home
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don't have to report or pay anything to HMRC if you pay no more than:

* £5 per night for travel within the UK
* £10 per night for travel outside of the UK

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If any of the overnight expenses you cover aren’t [exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-incidental-overnight-expenses/whats-exempt "exempt"), you may have to report the costs to HMRC, and deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on them.

The following table outlines what you need to report and pay for expenses above the £5 or £10 threshold:

Who gets the benefit | What to report | What to deduct or pay
-|-|-
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 | Nothing | Deduct and pay PAYE tax (but not Class 1 National Insurance) on the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-incidental-overnight-expenses/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit") through payroll
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more | Form P11D, section N | Deduct and pay PAYE tax (but not Class 1 National Insurance) on the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-incidental-overnight-expenses/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit") through payroll
Directors | Form P11D, section N | Deduct and pay PAYE tax (but not Class 1 National Insurance) on the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-incidental-overnight-expenses/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit") through payroll

*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What to report and pay

table.body: Use the full amount that you pay to your employee – not just the amount above the £5 or £10 threshold.
